Sort of simple thing that I can't seem to find documentation for:

Do I have to "compile" my theme when working on it locally?

I have my files, then I have a `/src` folder within it. I noticed that via `hs watch` or any other CLI commands, `/src` is not being updated with changes I make elsewhere in the theme. As such, any deleted files, updated files, etc. aren't be represented via watch or upload.

Any documentation out there for that `/src` folder, what it is, how to use it, etc?

Hello, thanks <@UBT0AHWLD>. That is the CLI reference, but there isn't any discussion in there between the relationship of the working directory and the `/src` child directory within it. Do you or anyone else know of a resource that explains it?

Basically, I'm not seeing any changes in my `/css` , `/js`, `/templates` etc directories "compile" to the `/src` directory, therefore updates aren't showing on things like the Landing Page Creation Workflow type areas.

Unless I'm missing something?

Hey Kris! It depends on your specific watch command. When using the watch command you specify a `src` directory (more info here: <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/developer-reference/local-development-cms-cli#watch>). This directory is then what is being watched when you run the watch command. In your case (based on your screenshots) if you're using the `watch` command on the `src` folder, it wouldn't pick up changes to adjacent folders like `images`, `js` , `templates`, etc. It would only pick up changes made within the `src` folder. The name of the directory doesn't matter (e.g. it can be `project-name` rather than `src`) but essentially the watch command will only watch whatever you set for the directory.

For example in boilerplate (<https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate>) there is a project folder and then a src folder within the project folder. In the top level project folder there are things like readme files, github specific files, etc. that we don't want being uploaded to a portal, therefore when you run the watch command on boilerplate you just target the `src` folder within the boilerplate project folder so it only pulls in what you want (and all files needed for the boilerplate theme are within that `src` folder). Hope that helps!

Hey thanks Jason! Okay, cool, I undestand that now. I guess what i don't understand is should I be `watching` at the

`/lp-demo`
or
`/lp-demo/src`

level? Because what I'm not understanding yet is how to ensure all changes at the `/lp-demo` level "compile" into `/lp-demo/src` directory, if that's what I'm watching.

OH. Interesting. So based on our most recent comment, what I'm hearing is:

• Theme directories are pretty "flat". It's `/theme` that should be watched
• The *Boilerplate Theme* (which is what I downloaded) has *examples* of all the stuff at the top level, but in reality the `/theme/src` directory are what I should have _copied out of this directory_ and into a newly created `/my-theme`  project
• Any subsequent theme I make *should not* include a `/src` directory because there really isn't a purpose for it within the CMS proper.
Is that right <@U26AKMZ19>?

So I might recommend a similar configuration to that boilerplate project above. In that case it would look something like:
LP Demo project:
• Top level files you don't want uploaded like `.github` , `bin`, `HubSpot.deploy`, `node_modules` (if you have any of these at all - not sure if you are working out of GitHub using something that would require this)
• A folder (named `src` or whatever you prefer to call it)  where your theme files live. This is what you would use the `watch` command on.
As far as theme directories go you can use different subdirectories within your `src` file/main project directory. That is up to your preference. Boilerplate uses several (e.g. templates is broken out into some different folders: <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate/tree/master/src/templates>). As far as boilerplate goes - yeah exactly you can use the top level stuff if you want but in reality what you need for the actual theme is `boilerplate-theme/src`. Any new theme you create doesn't _need_ a `src` folder within the main project folder but that method can be used if you have top level files/folders you don't want to include but you do want to keep grouped with your project.

So yeah in summary you could just rip the contents of the `src` folder from boilerplate and put them within a project folder named `lp-demo` and then run the watch command on the `lp-demo` directory. Really up to your preference!

Got it, thanks. I guess an extension learning question, then:

Why did the boilerplate theme put `/js` , `/templates` etc in that top level it's best practice to pretty much put all that within `/src`?

No problem :thumbsup: in regards to boilerplate there shouldn't be any top level theme files. Everything required for the theme should be within the `src` folder here (<https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate/tree/master/src>) and at the top level of the project (<https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate>) there are a lot of random GitHub/non theme files that we don't want uploaded which we keep outside of that `src` folder. I'm not 100% sure how those folders got out of the `src` folder for your project.
